ticketSummary.problem: The login button on mobile devices is not responding to touch events, preventing users from authenticating.
ticketSummary.solution: Adjust CSS touch-action properties and ensure JavaScript event handlers are properly bound so that the login button responds to taps on all mobile devices.
ticketSummary.context: This fix is part of the front-end authentication flow, ensuring mobile users can access their accounts through the login page.

configurationWarnings.title: Test case format mismatch
configurationWarnings.message: QA profile specifies gherkin format but one test case uses steps format.
configurationWarnings.recommendation: Use gherkin format for all test cases or adjust QA profile settings to allow steps format.

acceptanceCriteria.title: Login button responds to touch
acceptanceCriteria.description: The login button must respond to touch events on all mobile devices, including iOS Safari and Android Chrome.

acceptanceCriteria.title: Initiate authentication upon tap
acceptanceCriteria.description: Tapping the login button on mobile devices should initiate the authentication request to the server.

acceptanceCriteria.title: Touch target accessibility
acceptanceCriteria.description: The login button must meet minimum touch target size (44x44px) and be accessible via assistive technologies.

testCase.scenario: User taps login button on mobile to authenticate
given: User is on the login screen on a mobile device
The login button is visible and enabled
then: A touch event is received by the button
A login request is sent to the server
User is redirected to the dashboard

testCase.title: UI feedback and event handling for login button on mobile
testCase.objective: Verify that the login button provides visual feedback and correctly handles touch events on iOS Safari and Android Chrome
preconditions: Login page is loaded on mobile device
Login button is visible on screen

steps.action: Tap on the login button in iOS Safari
steps.expectedResult: Button shows active/pressed state and login process initiates

steps.action: Tap on the login button in Android Chrome
steps.expectedResult: Button shows active/pressed state and login process initiates

postconditions: User sees loading indicator or is redirected
